turns.speaker: SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: I'm sorry. No.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Please. I'll give it back, I promise. Please, sir.

turns.speaker: SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: My answer is no, Mozart.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: I know your work well, Signore. Do you know I actually composed some variations on a melody of yours?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Mio caro Adone.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Ah!

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: A funny little tune, but it yielded some good things.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Love, Sire!

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Ah, love! Well of course in Italy we know nothing about that.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Yes! yes! er, on  the whole, yes, Majesty.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: But this is absurd!

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Dear Mozart, my sincere congratulations.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Did you like it, then?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: How could I not?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: It really is the best music one can hear in Vienna today. Don't you agree?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Herr Mozart, what brings you here?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Your Excellency, you requested some specimens of my work. Here they are. I don't have to tell you how much I need your help. I truly appreciate your looking at these. I have pressures on me - financial pressures. As you know, I'm a married man now.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: So you are. How is your pretty wife?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: She is well. She is - well, actually, I'm about to become a father! She only told me last night. You are the first to know.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: I'm flattered. And congratulations to you, of course.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: So you see, this post is very important to me right now.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Why didn't you come to me yesterday, Mozart? This is a most painful situation. Yesterday I could have helped you. Today, I can't.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Why? Here is the music. It's here. I am submitting it humbly. Isn't that what you wanted?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: I have just come from the palace. The post has been filled.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Filled? That's impossible! They haven't even seen my work. I need this post. Please, can't you help me? Please!

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: My dear Mozart, there is no one in the world I would rather help, but now it is too late.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Whom did they choose?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Herr Sommer.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Sommer? Herr Sommer? But the man's a fool! He's a total mediocrity.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: No, no, no: he has yet to achieve mediocrity.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: But I can't lose this post, I simply can't! Excellency, please. Let's go to the palace, and you can explain to the Emperor that Herr Sommer is an awful choice. He could actually do musical harm to the Princess!

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: An implausible idea. Between you and me, no one in the world could do musical harm to the Princess Elizabeth.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Look, I must have pupils. Without pupils I can't manage.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: You don't mean to tell me you are living in poverty?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: No, but I'm broke. I'm always broke. I don't know why.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: It has been said, my friend, that you are inclined to live somewhat above your means.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: How can anyone say that? We have no cook, no maid. We have no footman. Nothing at all!

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: How is that possible? You give concerts, don't you? I hear they are quite successful.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: They're stupendously successful. You can't get a seat. The only problem is none will hire me. They all want to hear me play, but they won't let me teach their daughters. As if I was some kind of fiend. I'm not a fiend!

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Of course not.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Do you have a daughter?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: I'm afraid not.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Well, could you lend me some money till you have one? Then I'll teach her for free. That's a promise. Oh, I'm sorry. I'm being silly. Papa's right - I should put a padlock on my mouth. Seriously, is there any chance you could manage a loan? Only for six months, eight at most. After that I'll be the richest man in Vienna. I'll pay you back double. Anything. Name your terms. I'm not joking. I'm working on something that's going to explode like a bomb all over Europe!

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Ah, how exciting! Tell me more.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: I'd better not. It's a bit of a secret.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Come, come, Mozart; I'm interested. Truly.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Actually, it's a big secret. Oh, this is delicious! What is it?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Cream cheese mixed with granulated sugar and suffused with rum. Crema al Mascarpone.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Ah. Italian?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Forgive me. We all have patriotic feelings of some kind.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Two thousand, two hundred florins is all I need A hundred? Fifty?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: What exactly are you working on?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: I can't say. Really

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: I don't think you should become known in Vienna as a debtor, Mozart. However, I know a very distinguished gentleman I could recommend to you. And he has a daughter. Will that do?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Wolfgang, what is it? Sta calmo, per favore. What's the matter?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: It's unbelievable! The Director has actually ripped out a huge section of my music. Pages of it.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Really? Why?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: I don't know. They say I've got to re-write the opera, but it's perfect as it is. I can't rewrite what's perfect. Can't you talk to him?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Why bother with Orsini-Rosenberg? He's obviously no friend of yours.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Oh, I could kill him! I mean really kill him. I actually threw the entire opera on the fire, he made me so angry!

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: You burned the score?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Oh no! My wife took it out in time.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: How fortunate.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: It's not fair that a man like that has power over our work.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: But there are those who have power over him. I think I'll take this up with the Emperor.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Oh, Excellency, would you?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: With all my heart, Mozart.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Thank you! Oh, thank you.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Nine performances! Nine! That's all it's had - and withdrawn.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: I know; it's outrageous. Still, if the public doesn't like one's work one has to accept the fact gracefully.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: But what is it they don't like?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Well, I can speak for the Emperor. You made too many demands on the royal ear. The poor man can't concentrate for more than an hour and you gave him four.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: What did you think of it yourself? Did you like it at all?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: I think it's marvelous. Truly.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: It's the best opera yet written. I know it! Why didn't they come?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: I think you overestimate our dear Viennese, my friend. Do you know you didn't even give them a good bang at the end of songs so they knew when to clap?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: I know, I know. Perhaps you should give me some lessons in that.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: I wouldn't presume. All the same, if it wouldn't be imposing, I would like you to see my new piece. It would be a tremendous honour for me.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Oh no, the honour would be all mine.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Grazie, mio caro, Wolfgang!

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Grazie, a lei, Signor Antonio!

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Mozart. It was good of you to come.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: How could I not?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Did my work please you?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: How could it not, Excellency?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: I never knew that music like that was possible.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: You flatter me.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Oh no! One hears such sounds and what can one say, but - Salieri!

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: I have come to commission work from you.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: What work?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: A Mass for the dead.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: What dead? Who is dead?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: A man who deserved a Requiem Mass and never got one.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: I am only a messenger. Do you accept? You will be paid well.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: How much?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: How long will you give me?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Work fast. And be sure to tell no one what you do. You will see me again soon.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: I don't have it yet. It's not finished. I'm sorry, but I need more time.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Are you neglecting my request?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: No, no! I promise you, I'll give you a wonderful piece - the best I ever can!

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: What happened? Is it over?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: I'm taking you home. You're not well.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: No, no. I have to get back. I have -

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Where is your wife?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Not here! She's not well, either. She went to the Spa.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: You mean she's not coming back?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: You're so good to me. Truly. Thank you.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: No, please.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: I mean to come to my opera. You are the only colleague who did.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: I would never miss anything that you had written. You must know that.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: This is only a vaudeville.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Oh no. It is a sublime piece. The grandest operone. I tell you, you are the greatest composer known to me.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Do you mean that?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: I do.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: I have bad fancies. I don't sleep well anymore. Then I drink too much, and think stupid things.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Are you ill?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: The doctor thinks I am. But -

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: I'm too young to be so sick.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Shall I answer it?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: No! No, it's him!

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: The man. He's here.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: What man?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Wait! Ask him if he'd give me some money now. Tell him if he would, that would help me finish it.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Finish what?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: He knows. He knows!

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Another? But that's too soon! Tomorrow night? It's impossible! Did he say a hundred?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Yes. Can I - could I help you, in any way?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Would you? Actually, you could.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: My dear friend, it would be my greatest pleasure.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: But you'd have to swear not to tell a soul. I'm not allowed.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: You know, it's all here in my head. It's just ready to be set down. But when I'm dizzy like this my eyes won't focus. I can't write.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Then, let us try together. I'd regard it as such an honour. Tell me, what is this work?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: A Mass. A Mass for the Dead.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Where did I stop?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: The end of the Recordare - Statuens in parte dextra.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: So now the Confutatis. Confutatis Maledictis. When the wicked are confounded. Flammis acribus addictis. How would you translate that?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Consigned to flames of woe.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Do you believe in it?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: A fire which never dies. Burning one forever?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Oh, yes.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Strange!

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Come. Let's begin.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Confutatis Maledictis.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: We ended in F Major?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: So now - A minor. Suddenly.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: The Fire.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: What time?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Common time.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Start with the voices. Basses first. Second beat of the first measure - A.  Con-fu-ta-tis.  Second measure, second beat.  Ma-le-dic-tis.  G-sharp, of course.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Third measure, second beat starting on E.  Flam-mis a-cri-bus ad-dic-tis.  And fourth measure, fourth beat - D.  Ma-le-dic-tis, flam-mis a-cri-bus ad- dic-tis.  Do you have that?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: I think so.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Sing it back.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Good. Now the tenors. Fourth beat of the first measure - C.  Con-fu-ta-tis.  Second measure, fourth beat on D.  Ma-le-dic-tis.  All right?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Fourth measure, second beat - F.  Flam-mis a-cri-bus ad-dic-tis, flam- mis a-cri-bus ad-dic-tis.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Now the orchestra. Second bassoon and bass trombone with the basses. Identical notes and rhythm.  The first bassoon and tenor trombone -

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Please! Just one moment.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: It couldn't be simpler.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: First bassoon and tenor trombone - what?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: With the tenors.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Also identical?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Exactly. The instruments to go with the voices. Trumpets and timpani, tonic and dominant.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: And that's all?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Oh no. Now for the Fire.  Strings in unison - ostinato on all - like this.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Do you have me?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: I think so.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Show me.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: That's wonderful!

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Yes, yes - go on. The Voca Me. Suddenly sotto voce. Write that down: sotto voce, pianissimo. Voca me cum benedictis. Call me among the blessed.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: C Major. Sopranos and altos in thirds. Altos on C. Sopranos above.  Vo-ca, vo-ca me, vo-ca me cum be-ne- dic-tis.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Sopranos up to F on the second 'Voca'?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Yes, and on 'dictis'.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Yes!

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: And that's it. Do you have it?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: You go fast!

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Do you have it?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Then let me hear it. All of it. The whole thing from the beginning - now!

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Do you want to rest a bit?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Oh no. I'm not tired at all.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: We'll stop for just a moment. Then we'll do the Lacrimosa.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: I can keep going, I assure you. Shall we try?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Would you stay with me while I sleep a little?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: I'm not leaving you.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: I am so ashamed.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: What for?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: I was foolish. I thought you did not care for my work - or me. Forgive me. Forgive me!

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: Oh? Have I seen it?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: I - I don't think you have, Herr Director. Not yet. I mean, it's quite n - Of course, I'll show it to you immediately.

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: I think you'd better.

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: You mean in Turkey?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Exactly.

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: Then why especially does it have to be in German?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Well not especially. It can be in Turkish, if you really want. I don't care.

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: What you think, Mozart, is scarcely the point. It is what His Majesty thinks that counts.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: But, Your Majesty -

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: That will do, Herr Mozart!

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Just let me tell you how it begins.

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: Mozart! Herr Mozart, may I have a word with you please. Right away.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Certainly, Herr Director.

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: Did you not know that His Majesty has expressly forbidden ballet in his operas?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Yes, but this is not a ballet. This is a dance at Figaro's wedding.

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: Exactly. A dance.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: But surely the Emperor didn't mean to prohibit dancing when it's part of the story.

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: It is dangerous for you to interpret His Majesty's edicts. Give me your score, please.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: What are you doing, Herr Director?

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: Taking out what you should never have put in.

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: Can we see the scene with the music back, please?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Oh yes, certainly. Certainly, Herr Director!

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: What is this, Herr Chamberlain?

turns.speaker: VON STRACK
turns.text: What is what?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Why do I have to submit samples of my work to some stupid committee? Just to teach a sixteen-year-old girl.

turns.speaker: VON STRACK
turns.text: Because His Majesty wishes it.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Is the Emperor angry with me?

turns.speaker: VON STRACK
turns.text: On the contrary.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Then why doesn't he simply appoint me to the post?

turns.speaker: VON STRACK
turns.text: Mozart, you are not the only composer in Vienna.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: No, but I'm the best.

turns.speaker: VON STRACK
turns.text: A little modesty would suit you better.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Who is on this committee?

turns.speaker: VON STRACK
turns.text: Kapellmeister Bonno, Count Orsini- Rosenberg and Court Composer Salieri.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Naturally, the Italians! Of course! Always the Italians!

turns.speaker: VON STRACK
turns.text: Mozart -

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: They hate my music. It terrifies them. The only sound Italians understand is banality. Tonic and dominant, tonic and dominant, from here to Resurrection!  Ba-ba! Ba-ba! Ba-ba! Ba-ba! Anything else is morbid.

turns.speaker: VON STRACK
turns.text: Mozart -

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Show them one interesting modulation and they faint. Ohime! Morbidezza! Morbidezza! Italians are musical idiots and you want them to judge my music!

turns.speaker: VON STRACK
turns.text: Look, young man, the issue is simple. If you want this post, you must submit your stuff in the same way as all your colleagues.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Must I? Well, I won't! I tell you straight: I will not!

turns.speaker: VON STRACK
turns.text: Herr Mozart -

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: May I just do that, Majesty? Show you how it begins? Just that?

turns.speaker: VON SWIETEN
turns.text: I don't think it was really decided, Director.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Oh, German! German! Please let it be German.

turns.speaker: VON SWIETEN
turns.text: My dear fellow, the language is not finally the point. Do you really think that subject is quite appropriate for a national theatre?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Why not? It's charming. I mean, I don't actually show concubines exposing their! their! It's not indecent!  It's highly moral, Majesty. It's full of proper German virtues. I swear it. Absolutely!

turns.speaker: VON SWIETEN
turns.text: Well done, Mozart. Really quite fine.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Baron!

turns.speaker: VON SWIETEN
turns.text: Mozart -

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Sire, only opera can do this. In a play, if more than one person speaks at the same time, it's just noise. No one can understand a word. But with music, with music you can have twenty individuals all talking at once, and it's not noise - it's a perfect harmony. Isn't that marvelous?

turns.speaker: VON SWIETEN
turns.text: Mozart, music is not the issue here. No one doubts your talent. It is your judgment of literature that's in question. Even with the politics taken out, this thing would still remain a vulgar farce. Why waste your spirit on such rubbish?  Surely you can choose more elevated themes?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Elevated? What does that mean? Elevated! The only thing a man should elevate is - oh, excuse me. I'm sorry. I'm stupid. But I am fed up to the teeth with elevated things! Old dead legends! How can we go on forever writing about gods and legends?

turns.speaker: VON SWIETEN
turns.text: Because they do. They go on forever - at least what they represent. The eternal in us, not the ephemeral. Opera is here to ennoble us. You and me, just as much as His Majesty.

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: I am Father Vogler. I am a Chaplain here. I thought you might like to talk to someone.

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: About what?

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: You tried to take your life. You do remember that, don't you?

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: In the sight of God that is a sin.

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: Do you understand that you have sinned? Gravely.

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: Leave me alone.

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: I cannot leave alone a soul in pain.

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: Do you know who I am? You never heard of me, did you?

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: That makes no difference. All men are equal in God's eyes.

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: Are they?

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: Offer me your confession. I can offer you God's forgiveness.

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: I do not seek forgiveness.

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: My son, there is something dreadful on your soul. Unburden it to me. I'm here only for you. Please talk to me.

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: How well are you trained in music?

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: I know a little. I studied it in my youth.

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: Here in Vienna.

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: Then you must know this.

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: I can't say I do. What is it?

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: I'm surprised you don't know. It was a very popular tune in its day. I wrote it. How about this?

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: I regret it is not too familiar.

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: Can you recall no melody of mine? I was the most famous composer in Europe when you were still a boy. I wrote forty operas alone. What about this little thing?

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: Oh, I know that! That's charming!  I didn't know you wrote that.

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: I didn't. That was Mozart. Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart. You know who that is?

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: Of course. The man you accuse yourself of killing.

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: Ah - you've heard that?

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: All Vienna has heard that.

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: And do they believe it?

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: Is it true?

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: Do you believe it?

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: Should I?

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: Do you hear me?

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: He was murdered, Father! Mozart! Cruelly murdered.

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: It was incomprehensible. What was God up to? Here I was denying all my natural lust in order to deserve God's gift and there was Mozart indulging his in all directions - even though engaged to be married! - and no rebuke at all! Was it possible I was being tested? Was God expecting me to offer forgiveness in the face of every offense, no matter how painful? That was very possible. All the same, why him? Why use Mozart to teach me lessons in humility? My heart was filling up with such hatred for that little man. For the first time in my life I began to know really violent thoughts. I couldn't stop them.

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: Did you try?

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: Every day. Sometimes for hours I would pray!

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: Yes, Father. Yes! So much for my vow of chastity. What did it matter? Good, patient, hard-working, chaste - what did it matter? Had goodness made me a good composer? I realized it absolutely then - that moment: goodness is nothing in the furnace of art. And I was nothing to God.

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: You cannot say that!

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: No? Was Mozart a good man?

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: God's ways are not yours. And you are not here to question Him. Offer him the salt of penitence. He will give you back the bread of eternal life. He is all merciful. That is all you need to know.

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: All I ever wanted was to sing to Him. That's His doing, isn't it? He gave me that longing - then made me mute. Why? Tell me that. If He didn't want me to serve Him with music, why implant the desire, like a lust in my body, then deny me the talent? Go on, tell me! Speak for Him!

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: My son, no one can speak for God.

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: Oh? I thought you did so every day. So speak now. Answer me!

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: I do not claim to unravel the mysteries. I treasure them. As you should.

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: Oh yes, yes, yes, yes, yes! Always the same stale answers!  There is no God of Mercy, Father. Just a God of torture.

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: His funeral - imagine it! The Cathedral, all Vienna sitting there. His coffin, Mozart's little coffin in the middle. And suddenly in that silence, music. A divine music bursts out over them all, a great Mass of Death: Requiem Mass for Wolfgang Mozart, composed by his devoted friend Antonio Salieri. What sublimity! What depth! What passion in the music! Salieri has been touched by God at last. And God, forced to listen. Powerless - powerless to stop it. I at the end, for once, laughing at Him. Do you understand? Do you?

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: The only thing that worried me was the actual killing. How does one do that? How does one kill a man? It's one thing to dream about it. It's very different when you have to do it, with your own hands.

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: Why? Why? Why? Why add to your misery by confessing to murder? You didn't kill him.

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: I did.

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: No, you didn't!

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: I poisoned his life.

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: But not his body.

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: What difference does that make?

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: My son, why should you want all Vienna to believe you a murderer? Is that your penance? Is it?

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: No, Father. From now on no one will be able to speak of Mozart without thinking of me. Whenever they say Mozart with love, they'll have to say Salieri with loathing. And that's my immortality - at last! Our names will  be tied together for eternity - his in fame and mine in infamy. At least it's better than the total oblivion he'd planned for me, your merciful God!

turns.speaker: VOGLER
turns.text: Oh my son, my poor son!

turns.speaker: OLD SALIERI
turns.text: Don't pity me. Pity yourself. You serve a wicked God. He killed Mozart, not I. Took him, snatched him away, without pity. He destroyed His beloved rather than let a mediocrity like me get the smallest share in his glory. He doesn't care. Understand that. God cares nothing for the man He denies and nothing either for the man He uses. He broke Mozart in half when He'd finished with him, and threw him away. Like an old, worn out flute.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: I've just learned something that might be of interest to you, Herr Director.

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Mozart is writing a new opera. An Italian opera.

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: Italian?

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: You mean that play?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Exactly.

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: He's setting that play to music?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: You must be mad.

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: Are you absolutely sure?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: I've seen the manuscript.

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Never mind.

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: Well, Mozart is already rehearsing.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Incredible.

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: The Emperor has given him permission.

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: What anger?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: About the ballet.

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: Ballet? What ballet?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Excuse me - didn't His Majesty specifically forbid ballet in his opera?

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: Yes, absolutely. Is there a ballet in Figaro?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Yes, in the third act.

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: Bravo, Your Majesty!

turns.speaker: VON STRACK
turns.text: Well done, Sire!

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: Well, actually, Sire, if you remember, we did finally incline to Italian.

turns.speaker: VON STRACK
turns.text: Did we?

turns.speaker: VON STRACK
turns.text: I know we banned this play, but frankly I can't remember why. Can you refresh my memory, Herr Director?

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: For the same reason, Herr Chamberlain, that it was banned in France.

turns.speaker: VON STRACK
turns.text: Oh yes, yes. And that was?

turns.speaker: ORSINI-ROSENBERG
turns.text: Well, the play makes a hero out of a valet. He outwits his noble master and exposes him as a lecher. Do you see the implications? This would be, in a grander situation, as if a Chamberlain were to expose an Emperor.

turns.speaker: VON STRACK
turns.text: Ah.

turns.speaker: UGLY OLD WOMAN
turns.text: Here I am, my angel.

turns.speaker: PAPAGENO
turns.text: What? Who the devil are you?

turns.speaker: UGLY OLD WOMAN
turns.text: I've taken pity on you, my angel. I heard your wish.

turns.speaker: PAPAGENO
turns.text: Oh. Well, thank you! How wonderful. Some people get all the luck.

turns.speaker: UGLY OLD WOMAN
turns.text: Now you've got to promise me faithfully you'll remain true to me forever. Then you'll see how tenderly your little birdie will love you.

turns.speaker: PAPAGENO
turns.text: I can't wait.

turns.speaker: UGLY OLD WOMAN
turns.text: Well, promise then.

turns.speaker: PAPAGENO
turns.text: What do you mean - now?

turns.speaker: UGLY OLD WOMAN
turns.text: Of course now. Right away, before I get any older.

turns.speaker: PAPAGENO
turns.text: Well, I don't know! I mean you're a delicious, delightful, delectable little bird, but don't you think you might be just a little tough?

turns.speaker: UGLY OLD WOMAN
turns.text: Oh, I'm tender enough for you, my boy. I'm tender enough for you.

turns.speaker: VON SWIETEN
turns.text: This is embarrassing, you know. You introduced Mozart to some of my friends and he's begging from practically all of them. It has to stop.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: I agree, Baron.

turns.speaker: VON SWIETEN
turns.text: Can't you think of anyone who might commission some work from him? I've done my best. I got him to arrange some Bach for my Sunday concerts. He got a fee - what I could afford. Can't you think of anyone who might do something for him?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: No, Baron, no. I'm afraid Mozart is a lost cause. He has managed to alienate practically the whole of Vienna. He is constantly drunk. He never pays his debts. I can't think of one person to whom I dare recommend him.

turns.speaker: VON SWIETEN
turns.text: How sad. It's tragic, isn't it? Such a talent.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Indeed. Just a moment - as a matter of fact I think I do know someone who could commission a work from him. A very appropriate person to do so. Yes.

turns.speaker: SERVANT
turns.text: Excuse me, sir, there is a lady who insists on talking to you.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Who is she?

turns.speaker: SERVANT
turns.text: She didn't say. But she says it's urgent.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Excuse me, my dear.

turns.speaker: SERVANT
turns.text: That lady is back, sir.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Show her in. Then go to bed.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: What does he want?

turns.speaker: SERVANT
turns.text: He didn't say, sir. I told him I didn't know when you would be back, but he insisted on waiting.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Come with me. And stay in the room.

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: Herr Salieri.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Yes, I am looking after him.

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: Can we come in?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Well, he's sleeping now. Better not.

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: But he's all right?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Oh, yes. He's just exhausted. He became dizzy, that's all. We should let him rest.

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: Well, tell him we were here, won't you?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: And say everything went wonderfully. A triumph-de-luxe - say that! Tell him the audience shouted his name a hundred times.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Bene.

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: I'll call tomorrow.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Yes.  And congratulations to all of you. It was superb.

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: Oh, by the way, give him this. This is his share. That should cheer him up, eh?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Yes, indeed. Goodnight to you all now. It was perfection - truly!

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Has the patient in twenty-one gotten his tray yet?

turns.speaker: ORDERLY
turns.text: The American? Yes, duck.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: How did he look?

turns.speaker: ORDERLY
turns.text: What do you mean, 'how did he look'?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: You know, did he seem depressed? Do you think he'll eat the food?

turns.speaker: ORDERLY
turns.text: I'm an orderly, not a bleeding psychiatrist! I push things about, but I've little say what happens to them.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Dr. Hirsch, Mr. Kessler cried out a minute ago.

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: Miss Gallagher, surely you must perform some function here at the hospital.

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: Can I be of service, Miss Price?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Dr. Hirsch?

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: Go about your duties.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Yes, Doctor.

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: Oh, Miss Price?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Yes, Doctor?

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: What exactly did he call out?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: He said 'Jack'.

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: That would be Jack Goodman, the boy who was killed.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: What happened to them?

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: The police report said an escaped lunatic attacked them. He must have been a very powerful man. Although I really don't see that it is any of your concern, Miss Price.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: No, sir. Of course, sir. Good day, Doctor.

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: Did he say a wolf?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Yes, I believe he did.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: It's all right, Susan. Yes, Doctor, I have.

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: Come to my office, Miss Price.

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: Oh dear girl, your extracurricular activities are of no consequence to me. I don't give a damn who you sleep with. I'm concerned about David.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: It's a full moon. Where is he?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: At my flat. I'm off at midnight and...

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: He's not?

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: Alex, has David persisted in his werewolf fantasies?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Well, yes, but he seems to be more upset by the death of his friend.

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: Has his friend appeared to him again?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: What did he say?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: David says Jack comes to warn him.

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: Warn him?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Dr. Hirsch, what's wrong? Is this more serious than I know?

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: I tried to investigate the attack. There are no records. The case was closed and now they've 'misplaced' the file. David's lacerations were cleaned and dressed when he arrived here and yet supposedly no doctor examined him before I did. The Goodman boy is already in the ground so he's no good to us. So I went to the pub in East Proctor where I was convinced of two things.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: They were lying. There were no witnesses, no escaped lunatic. The whole community is hiding the truth of what actually happened up there.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: And what else?

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: I think the village of East Proctor is hiding some dark and terrible secret. I'm convinced that, like David, they believe in this werewolf.

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: You've absolutely no idea where David might be?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: No. He knows no one in London, besides me. I shouldn't have left him alone.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Surely you're not suggesting...

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: David has suffered a severe trauma. I myself witnessed some form of mass neurosis in East Proctor. If all the villagers believe that Jack Goodman was killed by a werewolf, why shouldn't David? And then it follows that if he survived an attack by a werewolf, wouldn't he himself become a werewolf the next full moon?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Dr. Hirsch?

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: Oh, I don't mean running about on all fours and howling at the moon. But in such a deranged state he could harm himself, or perhaps others.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: What shall we do?

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: Let's call the police and see if they can help us find our wandering boy.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: He's here.

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: Is he all right? Why didn't you call me? Where was he?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: He doesn't remember. He woke up at the zoo.

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: The zoo? Is he rational?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Yes, he is. He's very excited and confused, but he's not crazy, if that's what you mean.

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: Have you read the papers today? Have you listened to the radio or television?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: No, why?

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: Is David acting strangely?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: No, not really.

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: Could you get here without any trouble?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Yes, I should think so.

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: Right. Now listen carefully. I want you to bring David here. I want him in my care. I'll notify the police that we've found him. It is imperative that you bring him straight to the hospital. Do you understand?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Yes, Doctor.

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: You're certain he's lucid? You won't need any help?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: He's fine. We'll come right over.

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: Shall I send a car?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: No, a cab will be faster.

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: I expect you shortly.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: What shall we do?

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: Tea would be nice.

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: Nurse Hobbs said there's a disturbance in Leicester Square involving some sort of mad dog.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: David?

turns.speaker: DR. HIRSCH
turns.text: I doubt it. But it's something to do.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: It wasn't a lunatic.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I beg your pardon?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: It was a wolf.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: A wolf.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Mr. Kessler?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: You haven't eaten your lunch.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I'm not very hungry, thank you.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I'm afraid you have to eat something.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Please, really. I'm not hungry.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: You put me in an awkward position, Mr. Kessler.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: How is that?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Well, you're to take these after you've eaten. Now what kind of nurse would I be if I failed in so simple a task as giving out some pills?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Leave the pills. I'll take them later.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Sorry.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Aw come on, Miss Price!

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Call me Alex.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Aw come on, Alex!

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Shall I be forced to feed you, Mr. Kessler?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Call me David.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Shall I be forced to feed you, David?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: This is absurd. I'm not hungry. I don't want any food.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Let's try a little harder, shall we?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Will you give me a break?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: You're a very beautiful girl.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I thought you were asleep.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I was. What are you reading?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: 'A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court' by Mark Twain.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Do you like it?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I've just started it. My friend gave it to me.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: What do you dream about?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I dream of death mostly.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I'm sorry. I shouldn't have asked you.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: It's okay. I want to talk to you.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: How old are you?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: That's not really a very proper question.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: How old are you?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Twenty-eight.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I'm twenty-seven.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Now what do you want to talk about?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Was Jack Goodman your good friend?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: My best friend. My very best friend.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Shall I read to you?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: What? Oh, yes, please.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court by Samuel L. Clemens. This is after the preface but before chapter one: A Word of Explanation. You all right?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Yes, go on.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Ahem, A Word of Explanation. It was in Warwick Castle that I came across the curious stranger whom I am going to talk about. He attracted me by three things: his candid simplicity, his marvelous familiarity with ancient armor, and the restfulness of his company - for he did all the talking. We fell together as modest people will in the tail of the herd...

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Hello. You all right?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I'm sorry I woke you up.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Don't be silly. Can I get you something?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: No, thank you. Just keep me company for a while.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: That's easy enough.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I keep having these really terrible dreams. They are getting worse and I can't seem to stop them.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: David, your dreams will stop. You'll leave England and your bad memories; and then this will all fade away.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Will you come with me?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I'm serious. You don't know me and I know nothing about you. We have a perfect relationship.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Now, David, I said I would keep you company, but I meant right here and now.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Will you think about it?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: How did we get from your bad dreams to my taking a holiday with a patient?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Not just a patient -- me.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: You're being awfully forward, aren't you?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Forgive me, I'm trying to cheer myself up and an affair with a beautiful nurse seemed like just the thing to do it.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: All I am to you is a sex fantasy then?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Now I'm embarrassed.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Good. I thought for a moment I was the only embarrassed one in the room.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I'm a werewolf.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: A werewolf?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Are you better now?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I'll let you know the next full moon.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: You're to be discharged tomorrow. Will you be all right?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: My friend Jack was just here.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Your dead friend Jack?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Yeah. He says that I will become a monster in two days. What do you think?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: What do I think? You mean about the possibility of your becoming a monster in two days or about visits from dead friends?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I was dreaming again?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I would think so.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Yeah, I would think so, too.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: The kitchen.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Very nice.
